journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part C: Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science

title-group.article-title: Multi-tooth contact behavior of helical gear applying modified meshing equation

article-meta.aff: 1State Key Lab for Mechanical Transmission, Chongqing University, PR China
2School of Dynamic Systems, University of Cincinnati, USA

author-notes.corresp: Jianhong Wang, State Key Lab for Mechanical Transmission, Chongqing University, Chongqing 400044, PR China. Email: jhwang@cqu.edu.cn

abstract.p: In tooth contact analysis, the numerical process of searching for true contact lines or points is always a daunting task. The true contact lines for ideal helical gear transmission can be easily obtained through the helical gear meshing theory; however, in practice, this approach does not work well due to effect of tooth elasticity that shifts the contact lines from their ideal position. To address this problem, an approximate method to seek the true contact positions is proposed applying a modified meshing equation for a pair of helical gear with error free and no shaft deformation. First, the helical gear tooth deformation is calculated with the combination of contact mechanics and finite element method. Second, the deformed tooth flanks are fitted with Chebyshev polynomials. Third, the modified meshing equation is formulated by accounting for the influence of not only gear rigid body movement but also the gear deformation on the meshing process. Finally, the true contact points are determined by solving the correlated tooth flank equations, meshing equations, and force balance equations. The deformations of the gear and pinion teeth within the meshing plane are analyzed, and the contact load distributions along with the Von Mises stresses over a mesh cycle are examined. The study indicates that the proposed numerical method can yield true contact lines quickly while avoiding costly computational time in the traditional true contact line searching process that searches iteratively in the whole meshed tooth flank.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: As one of the most widely applied gear transmissions in industry, helical gear meshing behavior, especially the multi-tooth contact cases, has attracted much attention in the past. Ajmi and Velex1 discretized the gear bodies by applying two-noded shaft finite elements with bending, torsion and traction effects, represented the tooth deflection by Pasternak’s elastic foundations model, and then used the classical approximation based on semi-infinite elastic spaces to calculate tooth contact stiffness. Using these formulations, they simulated the quasi-static and dynamic behavior of solid wide-faced gear, and concluded that gear body distortions are critical to gear meshing behavior. Zhang and Fang2 generated the helical gear tooth surface by a rack cutter with a parabolic profile, set the contact condition through gear mesh theory and calculated the tooth surface gap between two meshing teeth. They further described a set of algebraic equations to determine the multi-tooth contact situations, and analyzed the meshing behavior of a pair of helical gear with small crossing angle. Their results show that the helical gear with small crossing angles have similar mesh characteristics and load distribution compared to those of parallel-axis gears. Litvin et al.3 established the normal and edge contact conditions by employing the gear mesh theory, formulated the equations of gear tooth surfaces with localized bearing contact and developed tooth contact analysis algorithms for aligned and misaligned involute helical gears. In another study by Litvin et al.,4 the modification of helical gears with double-crowned pinion and conventional involute helical gears to avoid point and edge contacts was studied. Those modifications led to substantial reduction in vibration and noise typically induced by misalignment. Their research works focused on the geared system computerized design, its generation of tooth forms, meshing simulation and then stress analysis. Kar and Mohanty5 focused on the contact line variation in a helical gear system that tends to induce not only friction force variation, friction torque variation and contact force variation at the bearings, but also gear mesh stiffness and damping variations. Hedlund and Lehtovaara6 introduced a model for helical gear tooth contact analysis incorporating tooth bending, shearing, and tooth foundation flexibility. They concluded that tooth foundation flexibility plays an essential role in contact load sharing between the meshing teeth, whereas the effect of contact flexibility is minor. Kawalec and Wiktor7 presented a method for the determination of equations representing cylindrical gear tooth modification. The modified tooth surface was formed with simulation of tool trajectory, and the tooth elasticity was accounted for using three-dimensional finite elements. Wang and Fong8 analyzed the contact characteristics of a pair of double-crowned helical gear whose tooth flank was double crowned with a cycloidal curve in the longitudinal direction and a circle in the profile direction. The tooth bearing contact of the mating tooth surfaces under various assembly cases was studied. The results show that the proposed double-crowned helical gear set is insensitive to axis misalignments and center distance variation. Miyoshi et al.9 proposed a composite analysis method that can quickly determine helical gear tooth contact load distribution for any load condition applying three steps: first, according to actual tooth flank shape, assembly error and tooth static deflection, the tooth true shape was determined; second, the static deflection distribution and share load were calculated; and finally the tooth contact load distribution was obtained by integrating the equation consisting of bending deflection and tooth contact deformation. In a more recent study, Kolivand and Kahraman10 proposed an algorithm to determine the locations and orientation of potential instantaneous contact lines between two rigid contacting tooth surfaces by constructing a new surface of roll angle.

As seen from above, even though many investigations have been carried out to study the contact behavior of helical gear, the contact characteristic still needs to be better understood. Most of challenges come from the complexity in the geometry of the helical gear involute tooth surface after deformation, which complicates the prediction of the true contact line. On the other hand, the lack of the fast calculation method to determine tooth deformation with high precision is also a hindrance to the investigation of the contact behavior of helical gear. This study attempts to address some of those difficulties mentioned above. In this study, the tooth surface deformation is determined using a combination of finite elements and contact mechanics and then is fitted as function of tooth surface parameters. Helical gear’s meshing equation after deformation is established through inserting the fitted deformation into the meshing equation of the ideal gears. The true contact lines are gained by solving the meshing equation. In addition, an improvement on Vijayakar’s11 method to calculate the tooth surface deformation by combination of finite elements and contact mechanics is proposed through determining the circle radius of the contact area by the least square method. Finally, it may be noted that this study represents an extension of the earlier studies documented in Wang et al.12

sec.title: Formulation
sec.p:
The helical geared rotor system of interest as shown in Figure 1 comprises of a pair of identical helical gears supported by four bearings. The global coordinate system xyz located at the center of the bearing 1 is defined as follows: the x-axis is directed normal to both shaft axes, the y-axis is perpendicular to both the shaft axis and x-axis, and the z-axis is aligned along the center of shaft 1. Pinion position as defined by coordinates x1y1z1 is supported on bearings 1 (B1) and 2 (B2) via shaft 1, and gear position as described by coordinates x2y2z2 is held by bearings 3 (B3) and 4 (B4) via shaft 2. The facewidths of the pinion and gear are given by b1 and b2. Figure 1.
Helical gear pair system and its coordinate systems used in the formulation.

sec.title: Involute surface
sec.p: Before proceeding any further, a transformation matrix between two coordinates should be defined. When a coordinate system of a rigid body rotates about the z-axis with an angle φ, the transformation matrix T1 describing this pair of motion can be defined as13 (1)T1(φ)=[cosφ-sinφ0sinφcosφ0001]

The profile Σ1 expressed in the coordinate system x1y1z1 is obtained by multiplying its expressions in the coordinate system x1'y1'z1' with the transformation matrix T1 (10)r1=T1(φ1)r1' (11)rθ1=T1(φ1)rθ1' (12)ru1=T1(φ1)ru1' (13)n1=T1(φ1)n1'

Similarly, the profile Σ2 expressed in the coordinate system x2y2z2 is (14)r2=T1(φ2)r2' (15)rθ2=T1(φ2)rθ2' (16)ru2=T1(φ2)ru2' (17)n2=T1(φ2)n2' With the help of equations (10) to (13) and (14) to (17), the position and their differences with respect to profile parameters of the tooth profile Σ1 and Σ2 are determined and they are foundations for the investigation of the gear’s contact behavior.

sec.title: Tooth deformation
sec.p:
The traditional block finite element with eight nodes is applied to account for the deformation of the gear. Figure 2 illustrates the discretization of a tooth in mesh with finite elements. The node is defined to possess translation coordinates u, v, and w corresponding to the x, y, and z-axes, respectively, that is qi = {ui, vi, wi}T for ith node, which is determined with finite elements except the nodes within a half cylinder with radius of rL in the vicinity of tooth contact area denoted by symbol Γ. According to Bathe15 the gear deformation q = [q1 q2 … qN]T (N is the number of degree of freedom) can be obtained from (18)q=K-1F(P) where K is the global stiffness matrix and F the vector of external force which is the function of contact load P. Figure 2.
Single tooth finite element model with applied contact loads.

The basis for the gear pair operation is the meshing action through the contact between mating teeth to transmit torque. Finite elements can be applied to represent the variation of the deformation within the element by the assumed displacement field function or also known as shape function. To facilitate the finite element calculation process, the shape function is generally constructed as linear or parabolic function. However, the gradients of the deformation and stress within the vicinity of the force action point are so dramatic that the shape function fails to represent the variation properly. An easy way to deal with this problem is to increase the finite element density but this usually results in a prohibitively large number of finite elements. Here, a method proposed earlier by Vijayakar11 is applied to calculate the deformation and stress within the vicinity of the contact points, which combines the finite element formulation and contact mechanics.

The deformation state and stress at the point A(ξ,η,ζ) are not only determined by the contact load pi, but also influenced by adjacent contact loads pi - 1 and pi + 1. However, it is obvious from equations (19) to (21) and (22) to (24) that the deformation state and stress drop dramatically as we move farther away from the point of interest. Therefore, it is unnecessary to integrate all the influences of load on the line but just a few loads near the point of interest with a bandwidth of B. As a result, the general deformations at the point A(ξ,η,ζ) can be written as (25)D'=∑j=i-B/2i+B/2{uξjvηjwζj}=14πG[0000ξζρi-B/23-(1-2v)ξρi-B/2(ρi-B/2+ζ)…0ηζρi-B/23-(1-2v)ηρi-B/2(ρi-B/2+ζ)…0ζ2ρi-B/23+2(1-v)ρi-B/2…000 0000ξζρi3-(1-2v)ξρi(ρi+ζ)…ξζρi+B/23-(1-2v)ξρi+B/2(ρi+B/2+ζ)0ηζρi3-(1-2v)ηρi(ρi+ζ)…ηζρi+B/23-(1-2v)ηρi+B/2(ρi+B/2+ζ)0ζ2ρi3+2(1-v)ρi…ζ2ρi+B/23+2(1-v)ρi+B/200000]{p1:pi-B/2:pi:pi+B/2:pn}=N'iP
where N'i is the deformation coefficient matrix for contact load pi and P the contact load vector.

Similarly, the general stress at the point A(ξ,η,ζ) is (26)σ'=∑j=i-B/2i+B/2{σξiσηiσζi}=12π[0000(1-2v)ri-B/22[(1-ζρi-B/2)ξ2-η2ri-B/22+ζη2ρi-B/23]-3ζξ2ρi-B/25…0(1-2v)ri-B/22[(1-ζρi-B/2)η2-ξ2ri-B/22+ζξ2ρi-B/23]-3ζη2ρi-B/25…0-3ζ3ρi-B/25…0000000(1-2v)ri2[(1-ζρi)ξ2-η2ri2+ζη2ρi3]-3ζξ2ρi5….(1-2v)ri+B/22[(1-ζρi+B/2)ξ2-η2ri+B/22+ζη2ρi+B/23]-3ζξ2ρi+B/250(1-2v)ri2[(1-ζρi)η2-ξ2ri2+ζξ2ρi3]-3ζη2ρi5…(1-2v)ri+B/22[(1-ζρi+B/2)η2-ξ2ri+B/22+ζξ2ρi+B/23]-3ζη2ρi+B/250-3ζ3ρi5…-3ζ3ρi+B/2500000]{p1:pi-B/2:pi:pi+B/2:pn}=Ci'P
where Ci' is the stress coefficient matrix for contact load pi.

The transformation matrix T2 from the local coordinate ξiηiζi at P(xi, yi, zi) to the gear coordinate xkykzk (k = 1 for pinion and 2 for gear) is (27)T2k(uk,θk,φk)=[rθkTnkTrukT](k=1,2) where the vector rθk, nk and ruk are defined in equations (10) to (13) and (14) to (17). Finally, the general deformation Dk and stress σk at the point A(ξ,η,ζ) expressed in the gear coordinate are (28)Dk=T2k(uk,θk,φk)D'k(k=1,2) (29)σk=T2k(uk,θk,φk)σ'k(k=1,2)
Next the half cylinder radius rL is going to be determined with the least square method.

sec.title: The determination of half cylinder radius rL
sec.p: The deformation state and stress in the gears are calculated with different physical disciplines. As noted earlier, the response field within the vicinity of the contact points or lines is determined using contact mechanics and the response on the other parts of the gear is handled using finite elements. Vijayakar11 proposed the use of the least square method to establish displacement compatible condition at the interface denoted by symbol L, which is adopted here in this study. However, two natural defects connect with his method: one is that the contact mechanics coverage is set artificially with random; the other the stresses at interface obtained from both disciplines are discontinuous.

Here, an improved method is proposed that assumes the continua of the stress across the interface and the equivalence of the stress at the interface for both disciplines. As shown in Figure 3, the interface surface L of half cylinder Γ is discretized with n section equally spaced in the axial direction and M in circumference. A series of intersection points are selected and indicated as Bi,m (i = 1, … , n, m = 1, … , M), the stresses on those points are used to represent the stress state on the whole surface. To facilitate the calculation, those points are selected within the gear cross-section of contact load P, which means that at the pi cross-section, the points are Bi,m (m = 1, … , M).

In the following development, the stress at Bi,m (m = 1, … , M) on the interface L is calculated. First, the intersection between the half cylinder Γ and cross-section at pi within the coordinate xkykzk in a half circle can be expressed as (30)(x-xi)2+(y-yi)2=rL2

With the help of the above equation, the coordinates of point Bi,m are determined by equally discreting the half circle. Obviously, the coordinates of point Bi,m are linear function of radius rL (31){xi,m=f1(rL)yi,m=f2(rL)zi,m=zi where f1 and f2 are function relating the rL and xi,m and yi,m. Then, the stresses σi,mL_fe at those points are obtained by finite elements with the given element nodal displacement qe15 (32)σi,mL_fe=B(ri,m,si,m,ti)qe(i=1,…,n,m=1,…,M) where within the symbol σi,mL_fe, the superscript L-fe means at the interface L and is calculated by finite element while subscript i,m refers to the corresponding point Bi,m. Also, B(ri,m, si,m,ti) is the strain–displacement matrix in which the rows of B are obtained by appropriately differentiating and combining the finite element shape function H, ri,m, si,m and ti are the local finite element coordinates determined with xi,m, yi,m and zi, and thus they are also the linear function of rL (33){ri,m=f3(rL)si,m=f4(rL)ti=f5(rL)

On the other hand, the stress σi,mL_cm at point Bi,m on the interface L can be derived from equation (29) as follows (34)σi,mL_cm=σk(uk,θk,φk,rL)(i=1…n,m=1…M) where the superscript L_cm refers to the interface L and calculated by applying contact mechanics. This proposed method assumes that the stresses at the point Bi,m (i = 1, … , n, m = 1, … , M) are equal, which is not generally true in practice. Therefore, the least square method is applied to minimize their differences (35)s=∑i=1n∑m=1M(σi,mL_fe-σi,mL_cm)2
Then, differentiating with respect to rL and set it to be zero yields (36)∂∂rL∑i=1n∑m=1M(σi,mL_fe-σi,mL_cm)2=0
The above problem represents a set of nonlinear algebraic equations that can be solved with numerical method such as Newton–Raphson method to obtain the optimal value of rL.

sec.title: Tooth flank displacement
sec.p: To calculate the displacement of a generic point at the tooth flank relative to the gear coordinate system, the radius RL of half cylinder should be determined first. Using this approach, the absolute displacements DA of a point inside the half cylinder relative to the gear coordinate system can be shown to be (37)DA=DAcm+1N∑i∑m(DBi,mL_fe-DBi,mL_cm) where DAcm is the displacement of the point A within the cylinder and determined by equation (28), and the second item on the right of the above equation is the average displacement difference of point Bi,m on the interface L as determined by the combined formulation applying both finite elements and contact mechanics.

On the other hand, when the generic point A is located outside of the half cylinder, its displacement can be directly determined by purely finite elements (38)DA=H(rA,sA,tA)qe where H(rA, sA, tA) is the finite element shape function matrix; and rA, sA and tA the local coordinate within finite element.

sec.title: Tooth flank deformation fit
sec.p: Due to the application of combination of contact mechanics and finite element, the deformation expression for the tooth flank is quite complicated. Furthermore, its differential with respect to tooth surface parameters is even more complex. To simply this task, the tooth flank deformation is fitted with Chebyshev polynomials using the least square method. The Chebyshev polynomials can be defined by the recursive relationship given by (39){T0(x)=1T1(x)=xTn+1(x)=2xTn(x)-Tn-1(x)-1≤x≤1

Given the above fit, then it is not too difficult to obtain the deformation from equation (37) for the point inside the cylinder and that from equation (38) for the point outside the cylinder. A series of the point ptf (xj, yj, zj) that are either the nodes or the midpoints of the element edge on the tooth flank are grouped in order to use their deformations qtf to represent the deflection of the whole tooth flank. Since the tooth is defined with two parameters θ and u, the coordinate of point ptf (θj, uj) can be obtained from equations (10) and (14) with their coordinate xj, yj and zj at a given gear position. Hence, the deformation qtf(θ, u) of a point on the tooth flank can be expressed as a function of its coordinate θ and u by applying the Chebyshev polynomials (40)qtf(θ,u)=∑p=0m∑s=0mapsTp(θ)Ts(u)
Here, the least square method is applied to determine the coefficient aps, which can be written as (41)Π=(qtf(θ,u)-∑p=0m∑s=0mapsTp(θ)Ts(u))2
Let ∂Π/∂aps=0 and T(θ, u) = [T0(θ)T0(u), … , Tm(θ)T0(u) T0(θ)T1(u), … , Tm(θ)T1(u), … , T0(θ)Tm(u), … ,

Tm(θ)Tm(u)]T can yield results of the coefficient vector aps = [a00, … , am0 a01, … , am1 a0m, … ,amm]T given by (42)aps=[∑j(T(θj,uj)⊗T(θj,uj)T)]-1 ×∑j(qtf(θj,uj)·T(θj,uj)) where ⊗ is Kronecker tensor product.

sec.title: Equation of meshing
sec.p: After the tooth deforms, the pinion’s tooth flank can be expressed as the sum of the tooth flank position before deformation as given by equations (10) and (11) and its deformation component expressed by equation (40), that are (43)r1=r1+qtf(θ1,u1) (44)r2=r2+qtf(θ2,u2)

Its unit differential with respect to parameter θ1 and u1, assuming the influences of deformation on the modulus are omitted, are given by (45)rθ1=r1θ+∂qtf(θ1,u1)∂θ1 (46)ru1=r1u+∂qtf(θ1,u1)∂u1 (47)n=-rθ1×ru1|rθ1×ru1|=T(φ)({-sinλb1sin(θ1+μ1)-sinλb1cos(θ1+μ1)cosλb1} +r1θ×∂qtf(θ1,u1)∂u1+r1u×∂qtf(θ1,u1)∂θ1)

According to Litvin 14, the expression for the relative velocity between the pinion and the gear may be represented as (48)v12=(ω1-ω2)×r1-a×ω2 where ω1 and ω2 are the vector of rotation angular velocity and a the vector of gear center. Hence, the equation of meshing is established based on the fact that the scale product between relative velocity and unit normal direction must be orthogonal, that is (49)f(φ,θ,μ,αt,u,λb,rρ,q)=n·v12=0 where αt is the gear transverse pressure angle and rρ the radius of pitch circle. Here, the superscript ‘1’ is omitted for simplicity.

Rearranging the above equation and simplifying one obtains (50)f(φ,θ,μ,αt,u,λb,rρ,q) =cos(φ-θ-μ)-cosαt¯ +((rθ×∂qtf(θ,u)∂u+ru×∂qtf(θ,u)∂θ) ×(T(φ)[rρ00]T-r)T/sinλb)¯¯=0 where the first item on the right side of the above equation is contributed by the gear rigid body motion while the second item represents the influence of the tooth elastic deformation on the gear mesh.

sec.title: Contact load vector P
sec.p: If the tooth deformation is not accounted for under an ideal setting, it is assumed that the contact loads distribute uniformly along the contact lines. However, if the helical gear system is regarded as flexible body, the deformation along the contact lines is no longer uniformly distributed. Due to the assumption of small deformation, the gear tooth contact load should be inversely proportional to the deformation on the contact line, that is (51)p1d1=p2d2=…=pndn where di is the separation distance at contact load pi due to gear deformation.
In addition, the sum of all contact load pi should balance out with the force exerted by the external torque T as given by (52)∑i=1npi=T/rb1

sec.title: Numerical analysis
sec.p:
The tooth contact behavior of a pair of helical gear similar to the one shown in Figure 1 is investigated. They are two identical helical gears and their physical parameters are listed in Table 1. The meshing plane is tangent to the base cylinders of both pinion and gear, and makes an angle of 69.4° with respect to the x-axis, as shown in Figure 4. Since the tooth contacts of the helical gear occur within the meshing plane, the tooth displacement and contact load distribution will be analyzed. Figure 4.
Meshing plane of helical gear system.
Table 1.
Design parameters for the example helical gears as shown in Figure 1.
Parameters Descriptions Values
m Modulus 6 mm
z Number of teeth 16
α Pressure angle 20°
B Helix angle 15°
B Tooth facewidth 0.06 m
V Poisson ratio 0.29
E Modulus of elasticity 2.09 × 1011 Pa
G Shear modulus of elasticity 3.88 × 1010 Pa

sec.title: Model solution
sec.p:
The proposed helical gear model contains strong nonlinearity due to its inherent tooth contact behavior. The well-known Newton–Raphson method17 is applied to solve this model since it is a powerful technique for solving equations numerically. The chart in Figure 5 shows the overall solution procedure of the model. Figure 5.
Flowchart of proposed solution process.

Next, the solution process for the proposed method is explained. To start the solution process, a uniform load distribution P is assumed first. Then, the tooth deformations inside the cylinder Γ are calculated applying contact mechanics in equations (25) to (29). The gear deformation outside of the cylinder Γ is calculated with the finite element method using equation (18). The tooth flank deformation qtf is obtained from equation (40) and inserted into equations (43) and (44) to gain the expression for deformed tooth flank. The real contact lines and contact point’s distance d are subsequently derived by simultaneously solving equations (43) to (49). With the aid of the distance d between contact points, the contact load P is modified. This iteration process is then repeated until the difference of the contact loads meet a specified tolerance. Finally, the gear deformation within the mesh plane, the contact load distribution and stress distribution are computed and analyzed.

sec.title: Mesh response
sec.p:
The contact lines of the pinion in the meshing plane are illustrated in Figure 6. The meshing plane is measured with its longitudinal direction drawn horizontally and z-axis is vertical. The pinion tooth root appears at the left of the meshing plane while its tooth tip is at the right and side of the meshing plane. In order to show the shift of the position of contact lines more clearly, the displacement along the x-axis at the contact lines are exaggerated in the figure. The contact lines with different external torques are distinguished with respect to line types. The solid lines represent the contact lines when the pinion is exerted no external torque, which is the ideal contact lines without considering the elasticity of the pinion and gear. The dashed lines show the contact lines with an external torque of 10 Nm and the dotted lines are for results with an external torque of 20 Nm. It is obvious that the tooth deformations within the meshing plane at contact lines are essentially proportional to the external torques, as expected. This result demonstrates the validation of the assumption of linear spring for tooth deformation as long as the deformation is small enough. Figure 6.
Contact lines within the meshing plane. The solid line depicts the theoretical contact lines, the dashed lines are the contact lines with a torque of 10 Nm, and the dotted lines are the contact lines with a torque of 20 Nm.

Figure 6 gives the contact lines of five positions, distinguished with different colors, within the meshing plane during a mesh cycle. Within the simulated mesh cycle, at the first section time, the first and second pairs of teeth are in contact, while the second and third pairs of teeth are in contact at the rest time. The three color lines (Black, Red and Cyan) at the upper right hand corner are the contact lines for the first pair of meshed teeth, the two color lines (Blue and Green) at the lower left corner are the contact lines for the third pair of meshed teeth, and the rest of the five lines (Black, Red, Cyan, Blue, and Green) at the middle the contact lines are for the second pair of meshed teeth. At first, the first and second pairs of teeth are in contact and their contact lines are indicated with black lines. Then as the pinion and gear rotate, the contact lines move to the upper right corner to the third position lines as indicated by cyan during which the first pair of teeth disengages, and the third pair of teeth comes in contact at the lower left corner of the meshing plane. This reflects the involute contact ratio of around 2 for this gear pair design. Finally, the simulated mesh cycle ends at the position the contact lines indicated by green lines.

Figure 7 illustrates the pinion involute tooth displacement distribution with a torque of 20 Nm within the meshing plane for a full mesh cycle. Like in Figure 6, Figure 7 is also divided into three areas by center lines to represent the pinion tooth displacement distribution within the meshing plane of three meshed tooth pairs. Area I shows the displacement of the first pair of meshed teeth, area II is the displacement of the second pair of meshed teeth, and area III is the displacement of the third pair of meshed teeth. Within each contact area, the contact lines move in the direction as indicated by the respective arrows. At the beginning of the meshed cycle, the first and second pairs of teeth are in contact. At this moment, the contact line has already swept 80% of tooth flank of the first tooth and it is approaching the tooth tip at the upper right corner of the meshing plane. At this position, the pinion tooth stiffness weakens and induces a large displacement at the contact line as shown by deep blue. However, the contact line just runs across 30% of tooth flank on the second tooth and it is approaching the middle of the meshing plane, thus the stronger tooth stiffness cause a relative small displacement as indicated by light blue. As the mating teeth cycles through the mesh, the first pair of teeth disengages from the upper right corner of the meshing plane and the third pair of teeth comes into contact at the lower left corner. Since the root area of the third tooth first engages and tooth stiffness is strongest at this position, the displacement at the first tooth of the pinion is quite small. As the pinion rotates, the contact lines on all teeth traverse from the tooth root to the tip. In summary, as the contact lines lie at the tooth root, relatively small displacements are induced, and as it comes to the tooth tip, relatively large displacement are observed. Figure 7.
The tooth displacement of pinion within the meshing plane.

The contact load distribution on the tooth of pinion is shown in Figure 8. It is obvious that the contact load distribution is mainly determined with the tooth instantaneous contact stiffness. Unlike the distribution of the tooth displacement, tooth contact load distribution in general becomes large at the tooth root and smaller at the tip due to the fact that the meshed teeth has a stronger instantaneous contact stiffness at tooth root and a relative weak instantaneous contact stiffness at tip. Since the contact line on the tooth flank is not parallel to the gear’s shaft, the contact load is not uniformly distributed even on the same contact line, a larger contact load appears at the section near to tooth root while a smaller contact load closer to the tip. It is also noted that there are contact load concentration phenomenon at the upper and lower left hand corners of the meshing plane, which correspond to the root-end of the tooth. Figure 8.
The tooth contact load distribution of pinion within the meshing plane.

sec.title: Pinion stress analysis
sec.p: Stress is always a main concern when analyzing the gear tooth contact behavior. The contact stress within the contact half cylinder can be obtained from equation (29), while the stress of a point outside the contact half cylinder is determined by finite elements similar to equation (32) and expressed as (53)σfe=B(r,s,t)qe where B(r, s, t) is the strain–displacement matrix and r, s, t the position of the point in finite element local coordinates. Also, qe the deformation vector of the nodes of the corresponding finite elements and it is determined from the gear deformation vector q applying equation (18). The stress vector is σfe=[σx σy σz τxy τyz τzx]T and the corresponding von Mises stress (54)σv=((σx-σy)2+(σy-σz)2+(σz-σx)2 + 6(τxy2+τyz2+τzx2))2

Figure 9 illustrates three von Mises stress distribution states assuming a torque of 20 Nm on the pinion. During a mesh cycle, there are three teeth (Tooth 1, Tooth 2, and Tooth 3) involved in contact as shown in the illustrations. Figure 9(a) shows the pinion von Mises stress state when Tooth 1 and Tooth 2 are in contact. At this moment of the onset of the simulation, Tooth 1 is going to quit the engagement and the contact on it occurs near the tooth top. There are two positions with large von Mises stress on the Tooth 1, one is the position just beneath the contact point at the end of the pinion with a value of 11.6 KPa, the other position locate at the root at the end with a value of 9.03 KPa. On Tooth 2, the largest von Mises stress appears on the intersection of the contact line and tooth root. Figure 9(b) illustrates the von Mises stress distribution on the pinion at the moment when Tooth 1 just quits the engagement and Tooth 3 comes into contact. In other words, Tooth 2 undertakes nearly all external load at this moment. The largest von Mises contact stress occurs beneath the contact point with a certain distance at the end of pinion with a value of 17 KPa and the largest stress at the tooth root is 7.51 KPa. Figure 9(c) describes the stress distribution on the pinion as Tooth 2 and Tooth 3 are in contact at the time when Tooth 2 is disengages. At this instance, the majority of the external load is carried by Tooth 3. The largest Von Mises stress still appears at the contact point near the tooth root. Figure 9.
The von Mises stress distribution on the pinion for: (a) Tooth 1 and Tooth 2 in contact; (b) only Tooth 2 in contact; and (c) Tooth 2 and Tooth 3 in contact.

Observation of the Von Mises stress distributions on the pinion as shown in Figure 9, it is concluded that there are two places with high stress on the tooth: one position is where the contact loads act, the materials undertake pressure load; the other is at the tooth root where bending stresses reach their highest value due to the fact that the tooth acts as a cantilever and the tooth root is its fixed end.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: A new method is proposed to investigate the multi-tooth contact behaviors of helical gear pairs. The gear structure response is divided into two parts: one is the contact half cylinder on the tooth calculated from contact mechanics, while the other is the rest of the gear determined applying finite elements. Assuming small deformation, the helical gear mesh equation after deformation is obtained by modifying the theoretical meshing equation. The modification involves adding the influences of the gear deformation on the meshing behavior. This numerical method can yield true contact line quickly and avoid costly computational time as compared to the traditional true contact line searching process that searches iteratively in the whole meshed tooth flank area. Numerical results show that the helical gear tooth deformations within the meshing plane at contact lines are essentially proportional to the external torques. Also, as the contact line approaches the root area, the smaller the displacement becomes, On the other hand, as the contact line approaches the tip, the larger the displacement gets. The contact load distribution between the mating teeth is mainly determined with the tooth instantaneous contact stiffness with respect to the stress distribution on the pinion. Two positions can easily induce high stresses, that is one is at the contact area; the other is at tooth root, as expected.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research is in part supported by Project No. CDJZR10110022 of the Fundamental Research Funds for the Central Universities.
